intro: Thelypodium lilacinum var. subumbellatum, commonly known as the purple thelypodium, is a flowering plant native to the eastern United States. It is a member of the Asteraceae family, characterized by its composite flower heads and alternate, lance-shaped leaves. The plant produces showy, violet to purple flowers that bloom in late summer, attracting pollinators such as bees and butterflies. It typically grows in moist, shaded environments like woodlands and stream banks, preferring well-drained, loamy soils. Its ornamental value makes it a sought-after plant for native gardeners and ecological restoration projects.
